newsitem.title: THAILAND: Thai markets ride finance storm, caution remains.
newsitem.headline: Thai markets ride finance storm, caution remains.

text.p: Thai financial markets ended a stormy week on a positive note on Friday as some investors appeared to digest a major revamp of the troubled finance sector and withdrawals from weak finance companies slowed.
But analysts cautioned that despite the turnaround after four successive days of hard knocks, the road ahead remained rocky.

"It could well drag on for a few more months. We might see some Thai macroeconomic indicators improve, but this is a different microeconomic problem that will linger on until investors are totally convinced," said the head of research at a foreign brokerage who declined to be named.
The stock market finished up 2.19 percent as bargain hunters bought cheap banking and finance stocks that brokers said may have been oversold this week.
The baht firmed late, rising to 25.920/930 against the dollar from 25.948/970 earlier in the day.

"In the afternoon, there was a lot more selling of dollars as the market became more settled in response to measures taken to help the finance sector. People feel the action might do good," said a Siam Commercial Bank dealer.
In a sweeping restructuring, Thai authorities on Monday ordered 10 finance firms, hard-hit by a liquidity crunch, to raise capital by a total of 8.25 billion baht ($317 million).
They also told banks and finance companies to raise provisions for bad loans, primarily to the depressed property sector, to 115 percent and 120 percent respectively from 100 percent.
Some analysts said a statement by IMF managing director Michel Camdessus expressing confidence in Thai authorities' handling of the economy had helped.

"I see them taking steps to address one of the vulnerabilities of the Thai economy... I am confident that the measures and the programme for the future will have the potential to carry the economy back on track for sustainable growth," Camdessus said in Hong Kong.
Camdessus's words were "a strong and encouraging statement", a Hong-Kong based Peregrine Investment executive said.

A run on deposits this week from the troubled finance firms slowed to about 3.5 billion baht in withdrawals on Thursday compared with a total of 10.4 billion baht cleared on Tuesday and Wednesday, he said.

"The market seems to have calmed down, and investors have come to realise that the measures imposed by the Bank of Thailand will eventually strengthen the sector," a central bank official told Reuters.
Analysts said the bitter pills prescribed to financial institutions would be hard to swallow, but had the potential to cure the illness.

"The measures, especially on the sub-standard assets, will usher a long and painful adjustment period. But at the end, we think the authorities did the right thing," said Suphavudh Saicheau of Phatra Thanakit Plc, one of Thailand's biggest finance and securities firms.

"Many finance firms might see zero profit for this year and next. And those small companies who cannot meet the requirement will eventually be taken over, leading to a more solid and healthy sector," he said.

The troubles were exacerbated by slow economic growth and a liquidity crunch caused by the Bank of Thailand's policy of maintaining high interest rates to deter speculation in the baht, which was hit by devaluation rumours last month.
Finance Minister Amnuay Viravan said on Friday that his ministry would issue zero-coupon bonds to raise funds to help sick finance firms.
